<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.

<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>

answer_single_response (void *cls,

                        const char *url,
                        const char *method,
                        const char *version,
                        const char *upload_data,
                        size_t *upload_data_size,
                        void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&

explanation: I did not include fragments that already use const qualification (e.g. "const char *url", "const char *method", "const char *version", "const char *upload_data") because they already satisfy Rule 8.13. The calls to strcmp and the use of those const char * parameters do not introduce additional pointer constness issues. The (void) casts used to mark parameters as unused do not affect whether the pointer types should be const-qualified. Other local code (such as the return statements and the call to MHD_queue_response) do not declare new pointer-to-object types that could be made const within this function, so they are not relevant to Rule 8.13 and were not included.
